SourceText: A creator god existed, and his name was Kane. However, it is not clear that he also enforced moral behaviour among humans. But, based on the fact that people prayed to him in temples, asking him to grant them things like wisdom and prosperity, perhaps it is reasonable to code him as "active". Admittedly, however, things are somewhat complicated by the fact that Kane was also assisted by the gods Ku and Lono during creation (though he himself played the dominant role), and that, when people prayed to Kane, they often prayed "through" lesser gods, e.g. family gods ('aumakua). Based on information provided by Beckwith[840], though we also made sure that our codings do not diverge from the supplementary materials in Watts et al. (2015)[841] NB This descriptive text refers to the period following European contact. The fact that certain elements of the ritual-religious system the Europeans encountered in Hawaii had probably been in place for a few centuries at first seemed sufficient to infer the presence of other elements, such as this one. However, this approach now seems too speculative.

"Each Purana tends to focus on a specific deity as the Supreme Being responsible for creating and ordering the world. [...] Thus, [for example,] Krishna [...] is a form of the supreme God who creates, maintains, and destroys the universe. In the Bhagavad Gita, Arjuna is permitted to glimpse Krishna’s cosmic form. He sees the entire universe, the sun, stars, and planets, and all the people gathered on the battlefield within the body of Krishna. Krishna tells him that everything that exists is part of himself, but that he is not limited to everything that exists. In other words, just as the Vedic Purusha extended ten finger-lengths beyond the created universe, so too Krishna is the entire cosmos and more." [691] “Among the cosmic laws that constitute dharma, the law of karma, or action, is especially relevant to rebirth. By the law of karma, every thought, word, and deed carries with it a like reaction. Beings are born, live, die, and are reborn based on their actions. Every good deed brings a reward, and every bad deed a punishment. The terms ‘reward’ and ‘punishment’ are deceptive, however; for karma is not seen as a set of rewards and punishments doled out by a just God, but in impersonal terms, as the working of natural law. Karma attracts reactions to moral agents like an ethical law of gravity. Benevolent actions produce good results for the person who engages in them. Similarly, actions intended to cause suffering will lead to suffering for those who commit them.” [692]

Allah created and governs the cosmos. At the resurrection (Hashr), Allah will send individuals to hell (Jahannam) or paradise (Cannat) after final judgment (Hisab) of their behavior (e.g. cheating, theft). "As an uncompromising and pure monotheistic religion, according to Islam, God is one and unique (tawhid); and He has no partner, no children and no parents. He is eternal and everywhere. He is Creator of the universe, which is not self-explanatory. He is merciful, compassionate and loving. He sent prophets to guide humankind, to tell us how to live like good individuals and be happy in this world and the hereafter." [373] "The fifth article of Islamic faith is belief in life after death. The life of this world and all that is in it will come to an end on a divinely appointed date, which is called the Last Day (Qiyamat). All human beings who have lived in the world will then be restored to life and will be presented before God. This is called resurrection (Hashr). The entire record of every person will be presented before God for final judgement (Hisab). Those who excel in goodness will be rewarded. Those whose evils and wrongdoings outweigh their good deeds will be punished. Those who are condemned and deserve punishment will be sent to hell (Jahannam). Those who emerge successfully from the final judgement will go to paradise (Cannat). [...]Muslims must desist from the practice of infanticide, from adultery, from killing unjustly, from robbing orphans, from cheating in trade, from believing false reports and from showing pride: ‘Do not slay your offspring for fear of want. It is We who provide for them, and for you. Indeed their killing is a great sin. Do not approach adultery, for it is an indecent thing and an evil way. Do not take the life which Allah has rendered sacrosanct, except for a just cause.... Do not approach the property of an orphan except in the way that is best (responsible investment) until he attains majority. Keep your covenants, for one is responsible for one's covenant. Give full measure when you measure, and weigh with even scales (when you weigh). This is better, and will be the best in the end. Do not go after that of which you have no knowledge, for (man's) eyes, ears and heart, each of these (senses) shall be closely questioned. Do not walk proudly on the earth (Qur'an, 17:31-7).'" [374]

There is clearly a High God, Önulap. 'Önulap is the highest of the gods. He is the father of the gods and human beings. Everything comes from him, including illness and misfortune. Everything is tinien Önulap (fate, messenger of the great spirit). Human beings too belong to Önulap. The Truk people believe that Whites are the first-born, the Blacks, the Kanakas, the younger children of the great spirit. They express this in the following phrase: “ Naun Önulap muänidi re uon, naun /7/ sodubudur kanaka.” Önulap also knows everything that human beings do, since a turn of speech runs: “ Si a fadal le mesen Önulap” (we walk in the presence of the great spirit). The gods and spirits are also subject to Önulap. Whatever they do they do only at his command. Since Önulap stands so high and also does not come down to the uanönu like most of the other gods, his individual worship is rarer. In important matters, for example, in case of war, he is invoked.'[698] It's not very clear whether Önulap himself punished or rewarded mortals, but it is clear that the gods in general actively intervened in human affairs--though possibly not on the basis of moral principles. 'The natives express the relationship of the önu to the human being and vice versa in the following parallelism: Emen a önubodede, a feiot; emen a önumamau a [unknown]au, “when one is obedient to the önu, then he is happy; but when he is rebellious toward the önu, then he is unhappy.” In other words: For one who obeys the spirits, it will go well; for one who disobeys them, it will go badly. Having everything go well is brought about by the protection of the önu; things go badly because of their inflicting punishment on human beings. Thus, everything adverse in the world is punishment for the violation of the commands or prohibitions which the önu, and especially Önulap, have imposed on h human beings. The Truk people also say about disagreeable events: tinien Önulap, that is, decree of the “Great Spirit.” When an önu punishes a human being, the natives express this in the phrase önu a ku, the spirit has bitten. This “bite” manifests itself in various ways: by the swelling of limbs, stiff neck, maimings, epilepsy, sudden death, etc. The “bites” are regularly directed [Page 29] against a person’s life, which accounts for the fact that the natives are concerned about manau, life, more than anything else. But by life they almost exclusively mean manauen inisit, life of the body, inasmuch as, despite their knowledge of the other world, they have no desire whatsoever to go to the other world.'

"I don't think the Incas would imbue Inti with omnipotence, and certainly not omniscience. Supernatural entities in the Andes had great powers, but the most powerful simply had the greatest power to act in their particular domain. For example, stories of the great mountain Pariaqaqa claim that it held the potential to end the universe, but it could not create a new one, nor could it act as a patron for military conquest. The creator Viracocha could make a new universe, but not necessarily provide the warmth, water, and fertility needed to sustain life."[585]At the major pilgrimage site at Lake Titicaca, "Inca priests waited for the pilgrims to 'confess,' interrogating them about the faults that they and their communities may have committed in the observance of the Inca state religion and other obligations. Hiding any failures was considered a grave sin, leading to the most terrible punishments for them and their people by the all-powerful and omniscient Sun god." [586] However, Alan Covey says that the gods mainly punished "insufficient reverence", and the (deified) ruler was seen as "the source of morality and law"[587].

The supernatural world of the Iroquois included numerous deities, the most important of which was Great Spirit, who was responsible for the creation of men, the plants and, animals and the forces of good in nature. The Iroquois believed that Great Spirit indirectly guided the lives of ordinary men. Other important deities were Thunderer and the Three Sisters, the spirits of Maize, Beans and Squash. Opposing the Great Spirit and the other forces of good were Evil Spirit and other lesser spirits responsible for disease and other misfortune. In the Iroquois view ordinary humans could not communicate directly with Great Spirit, but could do so indirectly by burning tobacco, which carried their prayers to the lesser spirits of good. The Iroquois regarded dreams as important supernatural signs and serious attention was given to interpreting dreams. It was believed that dreams expressed the desire of the soul and as a result the fulfillment of a dream was of paramount importance to the individual.'[921] According to Lewis Henry Morgan, the Great Spirit was the result of mixing pre-Christian beliefs with Christian ones, starting perhaps in the late seventeenth century. Given Morgan’s Victorian evolutionist proclivities, some of his claims may turn out to be incorrect under expert review. 'The beautiful and elevating conception of the Great Spirit watching over his red children from the heavens, and pleased with their good deeds, their prayers, and their sacrifices, has been known to the Indians only since the Gospel of Christ was preached to them. The primitive Indians, says W. P. Clark, in his valuable book, The Indian Sign Language, “were limited pantheists -- they did not believe that the universe taken as a whole was God; but that everything in the world had its spiritual essence made manifest in the forces and laws of nature.” Hence the regard of the Indian for the totem of his clan held much more of reverence than the feeling of a present-day Briton or American for the lion or the eagle. Not only was the clan totem reverenced, but each individual had his personal totem -- (in Algonquin manitou, in Iroquois oki ). In youth after certain exercises and fastings he waited for a dream, and whatever he dreamed of became his manitou on which his fortune depended, -- the Master of his Life, the Jesuits translated it. With one it might be a muskrat, with another a knife; and whatever the totemic object, it accompanied the Indian on his journeys and especially on the war-path. If the manitou were an animal, the skin, or the plumage of a bird, was taken as containing the spirit of the animal. It would seem that when the Senecas attacked Herkimer at Oriskany they left in their camp their baggage containing many of these totemic objects. The capture of this baggage by Gansevoort was an even greater calamity than their defeat by Herkimer, and after that day'[922] 'In addition to this limited pantheism the Iroquois recognized several personal deities. Ataentsic was the oldest of their deities, and dwelt with her grandson Jouskeha in a bark cabin in the land of souls. She has been connected with the Moon and he with the Sun. Areskoui, the God of War, is more evidently a Sun God. Most of the worship now given to the Great Spirit belongs historically to Areskoui. Tarenyawagon was much reverenced, for he was the sender of dreams, and Hiawatha was an actual hero raised after his death to a place in the Iroquois Pantheon. The Iroquois religion was in a state of transition from pantheism to polytheism, and would soon have developed into a system like that of Rome where the nature worship was merged in that of the personal deities.'[923] 'There was however one deity worshipped throughout North America, the all-seeing one, the dweller in Heaven, the giver of many blessings, the Sun. To him were paid prayer and sacrifice and thanks for such good gifts as food, sunshine, and victory over the enemy. When the missionaries told of the God of the white man and his attributes, the account seemed credible to the Indian, who accepted much of it as further history of his Sun God; and the sacrifices, thanksgivings, and offerings were still offered to the Great Spirit as in earlier days to the Sun. Though the pleaching of Christianity made but slight direct impression upon the observances and actions of most of the Red Men, it did greatly affect their myths and beliefs, thus preparing the way for an ethical religion.'[924] That Iroquois supernatural beings were moralizing may be inferred from the fact that they appear to have enforced kinship obligations, in-group loyalty, and respect toward elders, though this is not as clear as in other religions. 'The fictive relations of kinship at the confederate level established st social relations among the Iroquois tribes. While at the local level kinship and fictive kinship ties define one's place in village and inter-village society. The myths of disorder and order established [Page 47] a set of relations where consensus, equity and hospitality were stressed. At the village level all the myths of disorder and order validated the authority of the elders, matrons and chiefs; while at the confederate level the epic of the establishment of the league validated the authority status of the civil chief. Actions harmful to the interests of those in positions of authority could result in cultural disaster and thus supernatural sanctions against factionalism existed.'[925]

Garo supernatural beings could be considered high gods, in that we define these as "a spiritual being who is believed to have created all reality and/or to be its ultimate governor". However, they did not punish or reward mortals on the basis of morality. 'The Garo believe in supernatural beings whom they call mite. This word may be glossed both as “gods” and as “spirits”. As Robbins Burling (1963:54), who studied the Garo in India, writes, the term mite “covers both beings whom we would call gods and certain lesser, quite different nuisances, which hardly deserve to be known by any term more dignified than spirits.” To some of these mite the Garo attribute the creation of all the creatures of the world, the control of natural phenomena and the granting of health, wealth and happiness to mankind. Other mite, they say, are the cause of illness, disease and other misfortune. Consequently, Garo talk of some mite as being good and friendly, because they can help mankind, and others as being invariably malicious. But, Garo say, friendly mite are also capable of causing sickness and misfortune, if people anger them. But whether beneficent or malicious, Garo do not terminologically differentiate the two kinds of mite. Furthermore they say that all mite, good or bad, need to be propitiated.' [1,062] 'No suggestion is made that a man’s behavior in this world affects his later destiny. Spirits and gods are amoral, and punishment for wrong behavior comes in this world or not at all. One treats the spirits and gods with respect and circumspection because they can cause sickness and crop failure, but they do not send these as punishment for immoral behavior. Morality has a more pragmatic basis. Nothing is wrong unless it hurts someone else, and one may expect that the other person and his family will take action against the wrongdoer. One need not wait for punishment from the gods.'[1,063]

Onyankopon created and governs the cosmos: this is clearly expressed in the first two of the following four quotes. The third and fourth clearly show that only those who follow obra (good conduct; e.g. reciprocity, mutual aid) join the Nana (ancestors) in the afterlife, and the third one implies (but, it should be noted, does not state clearly) that Onyankopon decides who has followed obra when it says that the Nana 'show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being.' 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[1,061] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.' [1,062] 'All ancestors are children of Nyame. Ancestors pass on to their children those things required of them by the Supreme Being as his children. They stand (mediate) between their children and the Supreme Being. They show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being. That good or right way is called conduct (obra) or good conduct (obra pa). The Ga people call it dzenba (world-coming) [Page 24] that is, way of being, or living, in this world; the way in which one makes good or behaves himself in the world.'[1,063] 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'

The following quote makes it clear the Zoroastrian god, Ahura Mazda, was both responsible for the creation of the world and for punishing transgressors. "[T]he prophet feels also the awe due to the God who is “Creator of all” (Y. 44.7), and who, as Lord of aša, presides over a strict justice for mankind by which the wicked, who have chosen to act “at Lie’s commands” (Y. 31.1) will be in due course condemned. Their destination is the Worst Existence, i.e., Hell, which has been brought into being by Angra Mainyu (Y. 30.4). Mazdā has “appointed recompenses” (Y. 43.5), decreeing that “the end shall be different for each” (Y. 48.4); but he “has left to men’s wills (the choice between) holy and unholy” (Y. 45.9), and it is their own inner selves (daēnā-) which lead sinners to destruction (Y. 51.13)."

“There are numerous Higher Gods, but these are remote and sublime beings who have little involvement in human affairs. Nevertheless, they are subject to karma and are eventually reborn like everyone else.”

The most important traditional religious teaching on this subject was that the gods required people to treat “strangers and suppliants” well. That is, you should assist strangers who come to your door in need (and definitely not harm them). You can see this when Odysseus disguised as a beggar receives hospitality (Homer was a basic school text in the Hellenistic period) or in the Hellenistic myth of Baucis and Philemon, a very poor elderly couple who received two strangers and gave them hospitality. The strangers turned out to be Zeus and Hermes, who rewarded the couple.” [327] "It is now evident that, for Hesiod, κακότης‎ represents moral badness and the opposite to virtue, arete. A bad man (κακὸς ἀνήρ‎) does not follow justice (δίκη‎) with his mind, and acts immorally; he represents a source of religious pollution and danger for his community. Just as Hesiod connects the bad man with injustice and religious danger, so he presents moral righteousness and adherence to justice (δίκη‎) as coexisting with ritual correctness. Gregory Nagy points out that in Op. 336–41, a passage which follows the lines quoted above, the moral correctness of δίκη‎ is ‘programmatically re-enforced by the ritual correctness of the just man’:26 Perses is again reminded that gods punish unjust deeds (ἄδικα ἔργα‎; vv. 325–34), and that he should often sacrifice purely and cleanly to the deathless gods and propitiate them often with libations and incense (vv. 336–41). Religious correctness is thus laid out as avoiding unjust deeds and as honouring the gods with sacrifices and libations.//"In vv. 325–34 the following deeds are listed as unjust (ἄδικα ἔργα‎): gaining wealth by force, stealing, or deception; wronging a suppliant or a guest; engaging in illicit sexual intercourse; offending orphans or aged parents. These offences span both the social and religious spheres. This is stressed at the end of the passage, where Hesiod states that such deeds provoke the anger of Zeus himself, who inflicts grave punishments (vv. 333–4). Effectively, Zeus holds the transgressor in agos. To sum up, in Hesiod’s poem, justice is represented as a goddess and as a law given to humans by Zeus. It governs all social and religious relationships; it encompasses religious correctness. Moral goodness equals adherence to justice, whereas ‘badness’ (κακία‎ or κακότης‎) is equal to injustice and religious transgression."

Allah created and governs the cosmos. At the resurrection (Hashr), Allah will send individuals to hell (Jahannam) or paradise (Cannat) after final judgment (Hisab) of their behavior (e.g. cheating, theft). "As an uncompromising and pure monotheistic religion, according to Islam, God is one and unique (tawhid); and He has no partner, no children and no parents. He is eternal and everywhere. He is Creator of the universe, which is not self-explanatory. He is merciful, compassionate and loving. He sent prophets to guide humankind, to tell us how to live like good individuals and be happy in this world and the hereafter." [455] "The fifth article of Islamic faith is belief in life after death. The life of this world and all that is in it will come to an end on a divinely appointed date, which is called the Last Day (Qiyamat). All human beings who have lived in the world will then be restored to life and will be presented before God. This is called resurrection (Hashr). The entire record of every person will be presented before God for final judgement (Hisab). Those who excel in goodness will be rewarded. Those whose evils and wrongdoings outweigh their good deeds will be punished. Those who are condemned and deserve punishment will be sent to hell (Jahannam). Those who emerge successfully from the final judgement will go to paradise (Cannat). [...]Muslims must desist from the practice of infanticide, from adultery, from killing unjustly, from robbing orphans, from cheating in trade, from believing false reports and from showing pride: ‘Do not slay your offspring for fear of want. It is We who provide for them, and for you. Indeed their killing is a great sin. Do not approach adultery, for it is an indecent thing and an evil way. Do not take the life which Allah has rendered sacrosanct, except for a just cause.... Do not approach the property of an orphan except in the way that is best (responsible investment) until he attains majority. Keep your covenants, for one is responsible for one's covenant. Give full measure when you measure, and weigh with even scales (when you weigh). This is better, and will be the best in the end. Do not go after that of which you have no knowledge, for (man's) eyes, ears and heart, each of these (senses) shall be closely questioned. Do not walk proudly on the earth (Qur'an, 17:31-7).'"

"The most important traditional religious teaching on this subject was that the gods required people to treat “strangers and suppliants” well. That is, you should assist strangers who come to your door in need (and definitely not harm them). You can see this when Odysseus disguised as a beggar receives hospitality (Homer was a basic school text in the Hellenistic period) or in the Hellenistic myth of Baucis and Philemon, a very poor elderly couple who received two strangers and gave them hospitality. The strangers turned out to be Zeus and Hermes, who rewarded the couple.” [329] "It is now evident that, for Hesiod, κακότης‎ represents moral badness and the opposite to virtue, arete. A bad man (κακὸς ἀνήρ‎) does not follow justice (δίκη‎) with his mind, and acts immorally; he represents a source of religious pollution and danger for his community. Just as Hesiod connects the bad man with injustice and religious danger, so he presents moral righteousness and adherence to justice (δίκη‎) as coexisting with ritual correctness. Gregory Nagy points out that in Op. 336–41, a passage which follows the lines quoted above, the moral correctness of δίκη‎ is ‘programmatically re-enforced by the ritual correctness of the just man’:26 Perses is again reminded that gods punish unjust deeds (ἄδικα ἔργα‎; vv. 325–34), and that he should often sacrifice purely and cleanly to the deathless gods and propitiate them often with libations and incense (vv. 336–41). Religious correctness is thus laid out as avoiding unjust deeds and as honouring the gods with sacrifices and libations.//"In vv. 325–34 the following deeds are listed as unjust (ἄδικα ἔργα‎): gaining wealth by force, stealing, or deception; wronging a suppliant or a guest; engaging in illicit sexual intercourse; offending orphans or aged parents. These offences span both the social and religious spheres. This is stressed at the end of the passage, where Hesiod states that such deeds provoke the anger of Zeus himself, who inflicts grave punishments (vv. 333–4). Effectively, Zeus holds the transgressor in agos. To sum up, in Hesiod’s poem, justice is represented as a goddess and as a law given to humans by Zeus. It governs all social and religious relationships; it encompasses religious correctness. Moral goodness equals adherence to justice, whereas ‘badness’ (κακία‎ or κακότης‎) is equal to injustice and religious transgression."

Yakut spirits and deities appear qualify as high gods, in that they have created and rule over reality. 'Originally, Tangara-the sky god, the father of the gods, typologically comparable to the Rigvedic D’iaus, and to the Latin concept of “god” (D’iaus-Deos-Theo)-was supposed to occupy the dominant position among the aiyy deities. Later, this image was embodied in the central figure of the Yakut pantheon, Iuriung Aiyy toion, the “White Creator God,” the god of light, the personified image of the Sun, with the functions of sovereign of the Universe. Then came the other aiyy deities. A particularly important place was occupied by Aal Uot ichchite, the spirit of sacred fire-both of the sacrificial flame and of the domestic hearth. Like the Arian Agni, Aal Uot ichchite was considered to be the protector of the family and the giver of good fortune and healthy offspring. If the goddess Ieiiekhsit was regarded as the messenger of Iuriung Aiyy toion, then the spirit of fire fulfilled the function of intermediary between earth and heaven, between humanity and the gods.' [817] However, it appears they were not moralizing. 'Very characteristic of the Yakut beliefs is the absence of conceptions of paradise and hell and the lack of any idea of retaliation as we understand it. The Yakut word aj[unknown]y usually translated, sin, means more properly, harm, damage; for instance, aj[unknown]y is used when milk is spoiled by a mouse falling into it, or, when a man’s bed is contaminated by a frog.'[818] 'The Yakut love life and hold the present in very high esteem, but the future, particularly that which will come after death, does not concern them particularly. Any conception of the aims of existence and of the future fate of all living things, of the end of the world, or of what will happen to a man after his death is relatively weakly developed among them. Those few ideas on the subject which they borrowed from the Russians together with Christianity have somehow dried up in their minds, become dim, and have been delegated to the background. If we except the pale and corrupted Biblical paraphrases of the end of the world, paradise, and hell, they have hardly any beliefs on the bond between life on earth and life after death in the sense of punishment or reward.'[819] 'The Yakut Satan, that allara abasy ogonior (the old man-spirit of the underworld) who is sometimes also called Satan, is a quite different conception, although recently he took has begun to take on some of the attributes of his Biblical equivalent. For example, he is called the king of the evil spirits, abasy yrakhta, although he is by no means considered to be the most powerful among the fetishes and spirits embodying the evil and harmful forces of nature. It is noteworthy that the Yakut world conception does not bear any mystical facets; they are aware of harmful, helpful, and indifferent phenomena, but no sinful phenomena. The concept of grace, as a result of the victory by the spirit over the body, mortification of the flesh, chastity, humility, and other ascetic ideals, is completely foreign to them. They have the word aji - sin, but the meaning of this word is quite different. I myself have not been able to establish completely just what concepts this word includes, but most probably it is the idea of suffering. In the past they said arakh; this is the same as aji. (Namsk Ulus, 1889). The concepts of faith as virtue and doubt as sin are both equally incomprehensible to them.'[820] 'I shall close this brief sketch of Yakut beliefs with a description of a cult which differs from all the gloomy beliefs I have heretofore described by its light and joyous character. The basis of this cult consists in the worship of fertility, abundance, wealth, and in general everything which aids in the maintenance and rebirth of life. All the gods, guardians, and bestowers of these blessings live in the east. Their priests are called the white or light shamans (yuryung ai oyuna) they were once called summer shamans (saingy), because the feasts (ysyakh) in honor of these divinities are usually held in the summer.' [821]

Beierle writes that 'There are no gods who play ethical or moral roles in the Jivaro pantheon'[1,017]. However, the following quote complicates things somewhat: first suggesting that the Jivaro were more concerned with witchcraft than moralising gods, then stating that supernatural beings determine daily events. 'The Jívaro believe that witchcraft is the cause of the vast majority of illnesses and non-violent deaths. Practically the only diseases not attributed to witchcraft are “white man's diseases” (suηurä), normally of an epidemic nature, [Page 153] such as whooping cough, measles, colds, and some mild diarrheas. The normal waking life, as noted before, is simply “a lie,” or illusion, while the true forces that determine daily events are supernatural and can only be seen and manipulated with the aid of hallucinogenic drugs. A reality view of this kind creates a demand for shamans, part-time specialists who can cross over into the “real” world at will to help others to deal with the forces that influence and even determine the events of the waking life.'[1,018] Overall, this suggests that supernatural beings were "present and active in human affairs but not supportive of human morality", which corresponds, for this variable, with an "active" code.

"The Bamana religion is based on the belief in one Supreme God, Maa Ngala, 'Lord of All,' or Masa Dembali, 'Uncreated and Infinite Lord.' God is responsible for creating the world and all that is in the world. It is both immanent and transcendent. The Orokaiva appear not to have had "high gods": 'Apart from the very faint hint which these last may give us there is nothing to suggest a deity or any supernatural being of independent existence, least of all a high-god. I do not know of any cosmogony, and there is no attribution of divine powers to the phenomena of nature. On the whole it will be found that Orokaiva religion concerns itself primarily with the spirits of the dead.'[930] However, they did have demi-gods, who they believed to be the source of moral principles: 'Orokaiva social philosophy differs from our own, in the first place by its refusal to recognise the authority of anyone outside the individual's extended family, a characteristic to which I shall give more attention later. If the Orokaiva, by and large, order their lives by the same moral principles, they would explain this by their common belief in certain demigods whom they all regard as their ancestors and as sources of authority, and who created certain institutions embodying moral norms to which they all subscribe. Not only do they obey the precepts of these demi-gods, they also re-enact their feats in ritual and identify with them during ceremonies, and in many of their regular expressive activities.'[931] 'I shall therefore attempt to reconstruct what these demi-gods are said to have taught the Orokaiva about social relations. This reconstruction requires a brief analysis of some myths in which these teachings are contained. The myths all refer to events in original time. I was told that men, in their primordial or pre-cultural state, were living by the top of Mount Lamington (Sumbiripa Kanekari), which is traditionally regarded by the Orokaiva as the centre of the universe (Schwimmer 1969). I collected a number of myths explaining the origin of death, strife, fire, houses, marriage, clothing and several other elements of culture. The demigods who transformed human life by introducing these gifts came ‘from the mountain’; Sumbiripa himself was the first man to die. He retired inside the mountain and all those who died later are said to stay with him inside the mountain. Hence the rumblings and tremors emitted by the volcano. Two published sources (Tomlin 1951, Benson 1955) show that these beliefs antedate the eruption of 1951.'[932] Having said this, no evidence could be found that these demi-gods (or any other supernatural being) punished or rewarded mortals on the basis of moral principles: there were ritual prohibitions against going near certain volcanic craters, lest the demi-god Sumbiripa became angry, and spirits living in the countryside were believed to occasionally attack people, but the "reason" for Sumbiripa's anger and the spirits' attack seem to stem more from transgressions against the gods than against other humans, or perhaps simply these beings' unpredictable nature. "Ritual prohibitions limited access to the area close to the crater as there was a belief that Sumbiripa, if disturbed, would be angry. There was also a great fear of the dead who were supposedly dwelling in the mountain. It is believed that the dead wander about the countryside, where they may attack humans. Sumbiripa is dangerous, even if he does not erupt, because he can send out his ghosts to cause misfortune among men. The myth about Sumbiripa Kanekari hints at the possibility of an earlier eruption by the account it gives of the origin of the crags existing before 1951.'[933] The separation between the human and 'wild' worlds was also important: 'The separation of man and pig leads immediately to the division of the world [Page 141] into two separate realms: the human world, comprising villages and gardens, and the wild world, ariri, the bush, where everything is dangerous and inimical to man, and where the ghosts (sovai) have their abode. The area friendly to man is thus reduced to a small space, whereas the area hostile to man is an infinite expanse. Thus man is forever at strife with all but a small circumscribed portion of the universe. The myth of pig-man restates in another idiom the message of the primal theft of the piece of string.'

Thomas Cressy: Coded as absent due to expert confirming that high gods were not present until Christianity[649] "For the Romans, proper respect for the gods and proper interpersonal behavior were both integral to pietas, the key virtue. Pietas included duty to the family, the parents, one’s patron, and the state, as well as the gods. The gods were the guarantors of the welfare of the state and the continuance of the social order. Thus violating the social order by transgressing the mos maiorum (ancestral custom in any domain) was offensive to gods and liable to bring bad results on the group. [...] However, I think it is fair to say (1) that the Romans were more interested in punishing transgressions themselves than in waiting for the gods to do it. In their view, it was important to root out and punish wrongdoers so that they did not further contravene the mos maiorum and (by definition) anger the gods. Such punishment could avert disasters. (2) Punishment from the gods was expected to occur as disasters affecting the group/state, such as plague or famine or battle loss, more than the striking down of guilty individuals; (3) What we think of as the distinction between ritual transgression and ethical transgression tends to be collapsed, with ethical wrongdoing very often brought under the aegis of the gods or redefined as an offense to the gods."

"The most important traditional religious teaching on this subject was that the gods required people to treat “strangers and suppliants” well. That is, you should assist strangers who come to your door in need (and definitely not harm them). You can see this when Odysseus disguised as a beggar receives hospitality (Homer was a basic school text in the Hellenistic period) or in the Hellenistic myth of Baucis and Philemon, a very poor elderly couple who received two strangers and gave them hospitality. The strangers turned out to be Zeus and Hermes, who rewarded the couple.” [587] "It is now evident that, for Hesiod, κακότης‎ represents moral badness and the opposite to virtue, arete. A bad man (κακὸς ἀνήρ‎) does not follow justice (δίκη‎) with his mind, and acts immorally; he represents a source of religious pollution and danger for his community. Just as Hesiod connects the bad man with injustice and religious danger, so he presents moral righteousness and adherence to justice (δίκη‎) as coexisting with ritual correctness. Gregory Nagy points out that in Op. 336–41, a passage which follows the lines quoted above, the moral correctness of δίκη‎ is ‘programmatically re-enforced by the ritual correctness of the just man’:26 Perses is again reminded that gods punish unjust deeds (ἄδικα ἔργα‎; vv. 325–34), and that he should often sacrifice purely and cleanly to the deathless gods and propitiate them often with libations and incense (vv. 336–41). Religious correctness is thus laid out as avoiding unjust deeds and as honouring the gods with sacrifices and libations.//"In vv. 325–34 the following deeds are listed as unjust (ἄδικα ἔργα‎): gaining wealth by force, stealing, or deception; wronging a suppliant or a guest; engaging in illicit sexual intercourse; offending orphans or aged parents. These offences span both the social and religious spheres. This is stressed at the end of the passage, where Hesiod states that such deeds provoke the anger of Zeus himself, who inflicts grave punishments (vv. 333–4). Effectively, Zeus holds the transgressor in agos. To sum up, in Hesiod’s poem, justice is represented as a goddess and as a law given to humans by Zeus. It governs all social and religious relationships; it encompasses religious correctness. Moral goodness equals adherence to justice, whereas ‘badness’ (κακία‎ or κακότης‎) is equal to injustice and religious transgression."

"The most important traditional religious teaching on this subject was that the gods required people to treat “strangers and suppliants” well. That is, you should assist strangers who come to your door in need (and definitely not harm them). You can see this when Odysseus disguised as a beggar receives hospitality (Homer was a basic school text in the Hellenistic period) or in the Hellenistic myth of Baucis and Philemon, a very poor elderly couple who received two strangers and gave them hospitality. The strangers turned out to be Zeus and Hermes, who rewarded the couple.” [587] "It is now evident that, for Hesiod, κακότης‎ represents moral badness and the opposite to virtue, arete. A bad man (κακὸς ἀνήρ‎) does not follow justice (δίκη‎) with his mind, and acts immorally; he represents a source of religious pollution and danger for his community. Just as Hesiod connects the bad man with injustice and religious danger, so he presents moral righteousness and adherence to justice (δίκη‎) as coexisting with ritual correctness. Gregory Nagy points out that in Op. 336–41, a passage which follows the lines quoted above, the moral correctness of δίκη‎ is ‘programmatically re-enforced by the ritual correctness of the just man’:26 Perses is again reminded that gods punish unjust deeds (ἄδικα ἔργα‎; vv. 325–34), and that he should often sacrifice purely and cleanly to the deathless gods and propitiate them often with libations and incense (vv. 336–41). Religious correctness is thus laid out as avoiding unjust deeds and as honouring the gods with sacrifices and libations.//"In vv. 325–34 the following deeds are listed as unjust (ἄδικα ἔργα‎): gaining wealth by force, stealing, or deception; wronging a suppliant or a guest; engaging in illicit sexual intercourse; offending orphans or aged parents. These offences span both the social and religious spheres. This is stressed at the end of the passage, where Hesiod states that such deeds provoke the anger of Zeus himself, who inflicts grave punishments (vv. 333–4). Effectively, Zeus holds the transgressor in agos. To sum up, in Hesiod’s poem, justice is represented as a goddess and as a law given to humans by Zeus. It governs all social and religious relationships; it encompasses religious correctness. Moral goodness equals adherence to justice, whereas ‘badness’ (κακία‎ or κακότης‎) is equal to injustice and religious transgression."

"As an uncompromising and pure monotheistic religion, according to Islam, God is one and unique (tawhid); and He has no partner, no children and no parents. He is eternal and everywhere. He is Creator of the universe, which is not self-explanatory. He is merciful, compassionate and loving. He sent prophets to guide humankind, to tell us how to live like good individuals and be happy in this world and the hereafter." [1,025] "The fifth article of Islamic faith is belief in life after death. The life of this world and all that is in it will come to an end on a divinely appointed date, which is called the Last Day (Qiyamat). All human beings who have lived in the world will then be restored to life and will be presented before God. This is called resurrection (Hashr). The entire record of every person will be presented before God for final judgement (Hisab). Those who excel in goodness will be rewarded. Those whose evils and wrongdoings outweigh their good deeds will be punished. Those who are condemned and deserve punishment will be sent to hell (Jahannam). Those who emerge successfully from the final judgement will go to paradise (Cannat). [...]Muslims must desist from the practice of infanticide, from adultery, from killing unjustly, from robbing orphans, from cheating in trade, from believing false reports and from showing pride: ‘Do not slay your offspring for fear of want. It is We who provide for them, and for you. Indeed their killing is a great sin. Do not approach adultery, for it is an indecent thing and an evil way. Do not take the life which Allah has rendered sacrosanct, except for a just cause.... Do not approach the property of an orphan except in the way that is best (responsible investment) until he attains majority. Keep your covenants, for one is responsible for one's covenant. Give full measure when you measure, and weigh with even scales (when you weigh). This is better, and will be the best in the end. Do not go after that of which you have no knowledge, for (man's) eyes, ears and heart, each of these (senses) shall be closely questioned. Do not walk proudly on the earth (Qur'an, 17:31-7).'"
